Science/Experiments/AtmosphereSurvey/Req: Must be flying on a body with atmosphere.
Science/Experiments/CrewReport/Data/Flav: You record the crew's assessment of the situation.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Da: You get detailed measurements of the environment.
Science/Experiments/EnvironmentSurvey/Sa: You obtain samples of the area.
Science/Experiments/CrewObservation/Data: You record the crew's assessment of the situation.
Science/Experiments/MarineSurvey/Data/Fl: You apply your science bits and bobs to the liquid.
Science/Experiments/MarineSurvey/Require: Part must be submerged in liquid or on the sea floor.
Science/Experiments/MarineSurvey/Sample/: You obtain a sample of the liquid to drink later.
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Data/F: You map the celestial body from far away.
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Requir: Must be flying in Low or High Orbit
Science/Experiments/OrbitalSurvey/Sample: You expose samples to the environment.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Data/F: You look at the sample container and give it a good shake.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Requir: Must be landed or floating on a liquid.
Science/Experiments/SurfaceSurvey/Sample: You give the sample container a lick.
Science/ResearchReports/Notifications/Do: Docking vessels have merged all Research Reports.
Science/ResearchReports/Notifications/EV: Boarding a vessel has added new Research Reports.
Science/TechNodes/Descriptions/tNode_0v_: Smaller engines for smaller aircraft. Now you can make your own personal jet!

Electronic probes and satellites are vitally important for exploring the vastness of space. Advanced computer-controlled craft can safely explore unknown regions and report their findings before we send our Kerbonauts, saving us time, effort, and snacks.

Fuel lines are designed to allow extremely volatile rocket propellant to flow safely between tanks in a number of useful ways. Don’t be fooled into thinking this is just a hose. Well, OK, it is just a hose, but it's the most high-tech hose you will ever see.

Reaction control systems are very small thrusters designed for stability and control in space. Placing these small thrusters around our vehicles will make maneuvering much more precise and help even the most inexperienced pilot fly like a pro.

As we build smaller satellites and exploration probes, we will need the technology to construct very small, efficient engines to propel them. Despite conventual wisdom, there are times when smaller is much better.
Small engines with a big purpose.

Studying methods of miniaturizing and compacting our science equipment into smaller, more efficient parts will greatly expand the ways we can utilize them, as well as reducing mass that can be used for other cargo, such as snacks. Science and snacks, what a great combination.
Making sure objects are supposed to glow like that.

Do not be deceived by the apparent small size of this technology. Strut connectors can be used in countless ways to strengthen a vehicle and are especially useful for holding together very large craft. Our simulations show that this will be an essential tool for any experienced rocket designer.
It’s surprising how many ways you can use a little square truss.
Landing legs on a spacecraft, what a marvelous idea!
Science/TechNodes/Descriptions/tNode_1v_: Reaction wheels use small gyroscopes to help provide stability without the use of thrusters. It would take too long to explain how something spinning at high speed can hold a ship perfectly still, but trust us, these things really work wonders!
Flying sideways is fun!
Technology designed to make anyone look like a good pilot.
Stuff to build stuff.
When you need to say goodbye, do it with explosions.

Connecting two ships together, or docking, is a cornerstone technology, and essential to our space program. Having the ability to dock two or more ships opens up all kinds of possibilities to transfer crew, fuel, and especially snacks, between ships.

When it comes to electrical efficiency, nothing beats a well-designed solar panel. These ingenious devices convert sunlight into electricity that can be used to run equipment and also recharge a craft’s batteries. Admit it, we all hate it when the lights go out.

Antennas are devices designed to transmit and receive radio signals and are a key component for our space center. By investing in better antenna technology, we are able to extend the range we can communicate to even the most distant planets. Impressive, isn’t it?
Who needs a crew?

This technology explores the idea of deployable and retractable solar panels, which offer a substantial boost in protection during dangerous ascents and descents through an atmosphere. The protective covers are also quite stylish.
Parts designed to physically shove your craft around.

Investing in payload technology will help us better protect sensitive equipment and cargo, such as electronics, scientific equipment, and most important, snacks. Payload fairings can even help improve aerodynamics and reduce drag during take-off. And make your ship look cooler.

With radial decouplers, we will be able to attach fuel tanks and engines to the sides of our craft, then discard them once they're empty, significantly increasing the thrust and range of our vessels. Pretty cool, huh?

A solid rocket booster, or SRB, is a powerful engine with fuel already built in. They are quite useful for providing a huge amount of thrust during the start of a launch, particularly with 2 or more radially attached. Because more power equals more fun, right?

With this technology we will explore advances in Specific Impulse, or ISP. Engines with high specific impulse are not always as powerful as lower ISP engines, but are more efficient and consume less fuel, making them quite useful in low gravity environments like space.
Because landing safely might be fun.

When it’s time to explore the surface of a planet, a rover is a Kerbalnaut’s best friend. These wheeled vehicles can be designed for any and all types of conditions and make traveling to alien terrains both convenient and fun.

With the environment scanner module equipped, your vessel will be able to gather more detailed reports from all over the Kerbollar system, which will translate to even more delicious blue science points for every fascinating new location you discover and explore.
When you really want to know what's going on around you.
This is the first step from firework rockets to real rockets. Fly safe, Kerbalnaut.
They’re trusses, not girders!

Researching survivability will help us to understand and build highly resistant heat shields for our craft. These are especially useful for re-entry into an atmosphere, where temperatures can climb high enough to roast marshmallows, along with the rest of your ship!
Ways to escape when things go horribly wrong.

Ion powered engines are a breakthrough technology. They have very little thrust, but the specific impulse is unparalleled, making them extremely useful for small exploration probes. They also emit a beautiful blue glow, so what’s not to like?
Science/TechNodes/Descriptions/tNode_2v_: A faster engine and a way to slow down before landing? What a treat!
It's surprising how fast these parts can make your craft look!
More stuff to carry more stuff.
A lot more things to build a lot more things.
Another batch of odds and ends to build things out of.
When you just have to say goodbye.
Parts to help bring Kerbals closer together!
Remember to wear insulated gloves.
Powerful antenna and some batteries to keep them running.

The Nuclear Engine for Rocket Vehicles, or NERV is a very efficient new type of engine. Even more exciting is that the NERV uses hydrogen for fuel, which has significantly less mass than methalox, making it quite useful for deep space missions. Ignore the green glow, it’s perfectly safe.
All sorts of parts to carry other parts and even some hitchhikers!
Power? What can go wrong?
Providing the best view on your craft!
Moar Power!
Turning your craft using just an engine? Is that even possible?
For your off-world, off-road driving pleasure.
Want to know if you can take your helmet off?
Keeping your science equipment dry at any depth!

It is important that we develop a large-scale science lab for our space program. Think of how much science we can learn if we could study individual regions on a planet or moon from low orbit! That should be well worth the cost in snacks.
Larger trusses mean larger ships.
All sorts of fun ways to attach trusses.
We’re providing you with a ladder. Don’t forget to bring it along.
Science/TechNodes/Descriptions/tNode_3v_: Big, pointy parts for your craft.
Strap yourself in and hold on tight. Things are about to get really, really fast!
Ever want to fly around the planet? Now you can.
Because spaceplanes are one of the coolest things you can build.
Enough fuel to circumnavigate a planet... twice.
Now you can have even more fun with trusses.
They can pilot a ship and beat you at your own game.
Further advances in the quest for unlimited power.
Trusses that store stuff for folks who need every part to serve a purpose.
Designed to hold massive amounts of snacks and some Kerbals!
Specializing in even bigger and better controlled explosions.
How big can a rocket engine get? You're about to find out!
Just when you thought you had enough trusses.
Science/TechNodes/Descriptions/tNode_4v_: Tubes, adapters, and nose cones, oh my!
Decouplers that pack quite a wallop.
So much more than just a ring.
More hydrogen for your nuclear engines.
That is a really big tank!
Just think how much stuff you can haul around now!
That is a whole lot of fuel!
Trucks on Dres? Have you seen that ridge?
More trusses in a variety of shapes and sizes for your building enjoyment.
Just when you thought you had enough trusses.
VAB/Messages/AssemblyContainsLockedParts: This build can't be launched because it contains locked parts.
Science/Notifications/Transmission_Out_O: Research Report: Transmission Failed, Out of Electrical Charge!
Science/Notifications/Transmission_Lost_: Research Report: Transmission Failed, Out of Range
Science/Notifications/ExperimentAlreadyS: Experiment for that region already in storage
Science/Notifications/ExperimentOutOfSto: Not enough research storage in vessel
Science/RDCenter/TechNodeInfo/Hidden: This tier and its contents are locked until you acquire the required prerequisites.
Science/RDCenter/TechNodeInfo/Visible: You still need prerequisites to research this technology!
Science/RDCenter/TechNodeInfo/Unaffordab: You don't have enough Science to research this technology!
Science/RDCenter/TechNodeInfo/Unlockable: You have the prerequisites to research this technology.
Science/RDCenter/TechNodeInfo/Unlocked: Congratulations! You now own this technology.
Science/Notifications/ResearchReportSubm: Your Research Report has earned you {0} Science Points
Science/ExperimentAction/ResearchOpportu: Perform Experiments here to earn new Research Reports.
Science/ExperimentAction/GoOutside: Some Experiments must be run by a Kerbal on EVA.
